title: Roundtrip conversions between Pint and yt units

content.raw: Since everything in this file relates to `pint`, maybe the name could reflect that and be less generic than `misc.py` to boot.
content.html: Since everything in this file relates to pint, maybe the name could reflect that and be less generic than misc.py to boot.

pullrequest.title: Roundtrip conversions between Pint and yt units

content.raw: @xarthisius can you install pint on the build machine?
content.html: Kacper Kowalik can you install pint on the build machine?

pullrequest.title: Roundtrip conversions between Pint and yt units

content.raw: I'm fine with changing it--I think the original motivation was that we might end up putting other stuff in here.
content.html: I'm fine with changing it--I think the original motivation was that we might end up putting other stuff in here.

pullrequest.title: Roundtrip conversions between Pint and yt units

content.raw: Now that you've added `arcsec` to the prefixable units, do we still need this? I guess so, since I think the name the unit system will generate is `marcsec`. I don't really have a strong feeling about whether or not `arcsec` should be prefixable.
content.html: Now that you've added arcsec to the prefixable units, do we still need this? I guess so, since I think the name the unit system will generate is marcsec. I don't really have a strong feeling about whether or not arcsec should be prefixable.

pullrequest.title: Roundtrip conversions between Pint and yt units

content.raw:
I was under the impression `mas` was a common abbreviation for observers. In general, it may be a bad idea to have prefixed units in the lookup table. 

On the other hand, I think that I added `arcsec` to the `prefixable_units` tuple in an earlier incarnation of this work which is no longer valid, so I could just also remove it.
content.html:
I was under the impression mas was a common abbreviation for observers. In general, it may be a bad idea to have prefixed units in the lookup table.

On the other hand, I think that I added arcsec to the prefixable_units tuple in an earlier incarnation of this work which is no longer valid, so I could just also remove it.

pullrequest.title: Roundtrip conversions between Pint and yt units

content.raw: I'd err on the side of removing it.
content.html: I'd err on the side of removing it.

pullrequest.title: Roundtrip conversions between Pint and yt units

content.raw: Sorry, which one? `mas` from the lookup table, or `arcsec` from `prefixable_units`?
content.html: Sorry, which one? mas from the lookup table, or arcsec from prefixable_units?

pullrequest.title: Roundtrip conversions between Pint and yt units

content.raw: I meant `arcsec` from the `prefixable_units` look-up table.

pullrequest.title: Roundtrip conversions between Pint and yt units

content.raw: `Pint` also uses the term `UnitRegistry`? That's a perhaps unfortunate name conflict. Maybe it would be worth emphasizing in the docstring that you're *not* looking for a yt `UnitRegistry`.
content.html: Pint also uses the term UnitRegistry? That's a perhaps unfortunate name conflict. Maybe it would be worth emphasizing in the docstring that you're not looking for a yt UnitRegistry.

pullrequest.title: Roundtrip conversions between Pint and yt units

content.raw: Maybe we should accept a yt `UnitRegistry` here?
content.html: Maybe we should accept a yt UnitRegistry here?

pullrequest.title: Roundtrip conversions between Pint and yt units

description:
[Pint](http://pint.readthedocs.org) is another popular package for handling units in Python. I decided to use one of its features recently, which necessitated converting between Pint and yt units. I decided to make a roundtrip conversion like we have for AstroPy. 

It was a little tricky, because Pint accepts a lot of aliases for the same unit, but always converts them to a format where you have the full name:

```python
from pint import UnitRegistry
ureg = UnitRegistry()
a = ureg.Quantity(1.0,"cm")
b = ureg.Quantity(1.0,"kg")
print(a,b)
``` 
```
1.0 centimeter 1.0 kilogram
```
And there's no way to back out the original way the unit was specified, or search for compatible representations. For this reason, I had to make a table of aliases for both the units and the prefixes in order for the conversions to work, see the new module `yt.units.misc`. 

There are other unit packages of course, but Pint seems to be the only one that is frequently updated and has a few features that we don't (and probably won't have a reason to have). 

I added tests and documentation, but for them to run, we'd need to install Pint on the test box. 

I also added the `mol` and `mp` units to the unit lookup table.
